holidays.name: Guy Fawkes Night
holidays.description: Also known as Bonfire Night, this British celebration marks the failed Gunpowder Plot of 1605, when Guy Fawkes tried to blow up the Houses of Parliament. People light bonfires, set off fireworks, and burn effigies of Guy Fawkes.
holidays.origin: Originated in England after Parliament was saved from the Gunpowder Plot.
holidays.funFact: The phrase 'Remember, remember the 5th of November' comes from a traditional rhyme associated with this day.

holidays.name: National Doughnut Day (UK)
holidays.description: While National Doughnut Day is usually in June in the U.S., in the UK November 5th is celebrated by some as a day to enjoy doughnuts, especially the jam-filled and custard varieties that go great with Bonfire Night treats.
holidays.origin: Derived from a British spin on celebrating beloved sweet treats during November festivities.
holidays.funFact: Doughnuts have been enjoyed in the UK for centuries, and special doughnut stands pop up around bonfire celebrations.

holidays.name: Knock Before You Talk Day
holidays.description: A quirky awareness day reminding us all to show common courtesy by knocking before entering someone's room or space, ensuring privacy and respect!
holidays.origin: An unofficial modern observance encouraging good manners and personal boundaries.
holidays.funFact: Many people admit they’ve been 'caught off guard' by someone barging in—today’s ideal to break that habit!

holidays.name: World Tsunami Awareness Day
holidays.description: An international day aimed at promoting awareness and preparedness for tsunamis, commemorating efforts to reduce tsunami risk worldwide.
holidays.origin: Designated by the United Nations to honor the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and encourage resilience.
holidays.funFact: The 2004 tsunami was one of the deadliest natural disasters in history, leading to better early warning systems globally.
